metadata.court: High Court Of Madhya Pradesh  At Jabalpur  Before  Hon

text:
[Cites 
6
, Cited by 
0
]

Madhya Pradesh High Court

Shitesh Gupta vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 25 April, 2024

Author: 
Dinesh Kumar Paliwal

Bench: 
Dinesh Kumar Paliwal

 1
 IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH
 AT JABALPUR
 BEFORE
 HON'BLE SHRI JUSTICE DINESH KUMAR PALIWAL
 ON THE 25 th OF APRIL, 2024
 MISC. CRIMINAL CASE No. 15107 of 2024

 BETWEEN:-
 SHITESH GUPTA S/O SHRI SHIVKUMAR GUPTA, AGED
 ABOUT 40 YEARS, OCCUPATION: BUSINESS RESIDENT
 OF NEAR HANUMAN MANDIR BEOHARI POLICE
 STATION BEOHARI DISTRICT SHAHDOL (MADHYA
 PRADESH)

 .....APPLICANT
 (BY SHRI MANISH DATT - SENIOR ADVOCATE WITH SHRI MAYANK
 SHARMA - ADVOCATE)

 AND
 THE STATE OF MADHYA PRADESH THROUGH POLICE
 S TATION BEOHARI DISTRICT SHAHDOL (MADHYA
 PRADESH)

 .....RESPONDENTS
 (BY SHRI AMIT DUBEY - PANEL LAWYER)

 This application coming on for admission this day, the court passed the
 following:
 ORDER

 This is third bail application filed by the applicant under 
Section 439
 of
 the Cr.P.C. for grant of regular bail relating to FIR No.172/2023, dated
 26.02.2023 registered at Police Station-Beohari, District - Shahdol (M.P.) for
 commission of offence punishable under 
Section 8
, 
21
 and 
22
 of the NDPS Act
 and under Section 5/13 of M.P. Drug Control Act. Applicant is in detention
 since 26.02.2023.

 2. Applicant's first bail application was dismissed as withdrawn and not

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: JASLEEN SINGH

SALUJA

Signing time: 4/25/2024

5:45:38 PM

 2

 pressed vide order dated 05.09.2023 passed in M.Cr.C.No.24925/2023. His
 second bail application was also dismissed as withdrawn and not pressed vide
 order dated 01.02.2024, passed in M.Cr.C.No.56793/2023.

 3. As per the prosecution story, on 26.02.2023, 25 Onrex Cough Syrup
 having codeine phosphate was seized from the possession of the present
 applicant. FIR was registered.

 4. Learned counsel for the applicant has submitted that applicant has not
 committed any offence. He is innocent. He has been falsely implicated. He is in
 jail for last more than one year. Therefore, it is prayed that applicant may be
 released on bail, pending the trial.

 5. On the other hand, learned counsel for the State opposed the prayer
 for grant of bail to the applicant and has submitted that seized quantity is a
 commercial quantity. Applicant has a criminal background of nine cases and
 out of these nine cases two cases of same nature under 
NDPS Act
 were
 registered against him in the year 2022 and this case has been registered in the
 year 2023. He is a habitual offender and is continuously involved in possessing
 and selling contraband. Therefore, he has prayed for rejection of this bail
 application.

 6. In this case a commercial quantity of contraband has been seized from
 the possession of the applicant. Undoubtedly, he is in jail for the last one year,
 but it cannot be overlooked that he is a habitual offender and except this case
 two cases under 
NDPS Act
 were registered against him and in the previous year
 i.e. 2022. 
Section 37
 of the NDPS Act put a bar on the grant of bail where a
 commercial quantity of contraband has been seized and its provision lays two
 limitations: (i) that Court is prima-facie of view that accused is not guilty of the
 offence and; (ii) he is not likely to commit any offence while on bail. As

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: JASLEEN SINGH

SALUJA

Signing time: 4/25/2024

5:45:38 PM

 3

 accused is already having criminal background of two cases under 
NDPS Act

 and after release on bail in those cases, he has been again found involved in
 same nature of offence and commercial quantity has been seized. Therefore, no
 opinion can be formed that he will not commit same type of offence while on
 bail. Hence, I am of the view that no case for grant of bail is made out.

 7. Consequently, this third bail application too under 
Section 439
 of the
 Code of Criminal Procedure for grant of bail filed on behalf of applicant -
 Shitesh Gupta is dismissed.

 (DINESH KUMAR PALIWAL)
 JUDGE
 Jasleen

Signature Not Verified

Signed by: JASLEEN SINGH

SALUJA

Signing time: 4/25/2024

5:45:38 PM

paragraphs.text: Shitesh Gupta vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 25 April, 2024

1
 IN THE HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH
 AT JABALPUR
 BEFORE
 HON'BLE SHRI JUSTICE DINESH KUMAR PALIWAL
 ON THE 25 th OF APRIL, 2024
 MISC. CRIMINAL CASE No. 15107 of 2024

BETWEEN:-
 SHITESH GUPTA S/O SHRI SHIVKUMAR GUPTA, AGED
 ABOUT 40 YEARS, OCCUPATION: BUSINESS RESIDENT
 OF NEAR HANUMAN MANDIR BEOHARI POLICE
 STATION BEOHARI DISTRICT SHAHDOL (MADHYA
 PRADESH)

.....APPLICANT
 (BY SHRI MANISH DATT - SENIOR ADVOCATE WITH SHRI MAYANK
 SHARMA - ADVOCATE)

AND
 THE STATE OF MADHYA PRADESH THROUGH POLICE
 S TATION BEOHARI DISTRICT SHAHDOL (MADHYA
 PRADESH)

This application coming on for admission this day, the court passed the
 following:
 ORDER

This is third bail application filed by the applicant under 
Section 439
 of
 the Cr.P.C. for grant of regular bail relating to FIR No.172/2023, dated
 26.02.2023 registered at Police Station-Beohari, District - Shahdol (M.P.) for
 commission of offence punishable under 
Section 8
, 
21
 and 
22
 of the NDPS Act
 and under Section 5/13 of M.P. Drug Control Act. Applicant is in detention
 since 26.02.2023.
2. Applicant's first bail application was dismissed as withdrawn and not

pressed vide order dated 05.09.2023 passed in M.Cr.C.No.24925/2023. His
 second bail application was also dismissed as withdrawn and not pressed vide
 order dated 01.02.2024, passed in M.Cr.C.No.56793/2023.

3. As per the prosecution story, on 26.02.2023, 25 Onrex Cough Syrup
 having codeine phosphate was seized from the possession of the present
 applicant. FIR was registered.

4. Learned counsel for the applicant has submitted that applicant has not
 committed any offence. He is innocent. He has been falsely implicated. He is in
 jail for last more than one year. Therefore, it is prayed that applicant may be
 released on bail, pending the trial.

5. On the other hand, learned counsel for the State opposed the prayer
 for grant of bail to the applicant and has submitted that seized quantity is a
 commercial quantity. Applicant has a criminal background of nine cases and
 out of these nine cases two cases of same nature under 
NDPS Act
 were
 registered against him in the year 2022 and this case has been registered in the
 year 2023. He is a habitual offender and is continuously involved in possessing
 and selling contraband. Therefore, he has prayed for rejection of this bail
 application.

6. In this case a commercial quantity of contraband has been seized from
 the possession of the applicant. Undoubtedly, he is in jail for the last one year,
 but it cannot be overlooked that he is a habitual offender and except this case
 two cases under 
NDPS Act
 were registered against him and in the previous year
 i.e. 2022. 
Section 37
 of the NDPS Act put a bar on the grant of bail where a
 commercial quantity of contraband has been seized and its provision lays two
 limitations: (i) that Court is prima-facie of view that accused is not guilty of the
 offence and; (ii) he is not likely to commit any offence while on bail. As

accused is already having criminal background of two cases under 
NDPS Act

and after release on bail in those cases, he has been again found involved in
 same nature of offence and commercial quantity has been seized. Therefore, no
 opinion can be formed that he will not commit same type of offence while on
 bail. Hence, I am of the view that no case for grant of bail is made out.

7. Consequently, this third bail application too under 
Section 439
 of the
 Code of Criminal Procedure for grant of bail filed on behalf of applicant -
 Shitesh Gupta is dismissed.

suggested_precedents.full_citation: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar, (2014) 8 SCC 273
suggested_precedents.legal_principle: Mandatory arrest not required for offences punishable less than 7 years
